issues.text: Does employment in stone-breaking or in stone-crushing operations carried on in mines specified in the impugned notification amount to employment in stone-breaking or stone-crushing which is item 8 in Part I of the Schedule to the Act?

issues.text: Is the impugned notification ultra vires s. 5(2) of the Minimum Wages Act?

anchor.surface_text: the impugned numberification is ultra vires s. 5 2  because stone-breaking and stone-crushing operations in manganese mines do number fall under any of the items in Part I of the Schedule.

issues.text: Can the appellant challenge the vires of the impugned notification without challenging the vires of the delegation under Art. 258?

anchor.surface_text: One more point still remains to be companysidered. Mr. Umrigar attempted to argue that the appellant cannot challenge the vires of the impugned numberification without challenging the vires of the delegation of authority effected by the numberification issued by the President of India under Art. 258 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Does the notification issued by the President under Art. 258 fasten upon the manganese mining industry the character of employment in stone-breaking or stone-crushing?

holdings.text: the stone-breaking or stone-crushing operations which are carried on in mines are not included in item 8 in the Schedule

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, our conclusion is that the stone-breaking or stone-crushing operations which are carried on in mines are not included in item 8 in the Schedule and if that be the true position the impugned notification issued by the State Government under s. 5 2  is ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of Schedule excludes manganese mines/quarries distinction; ordinary parlance limits 'stone' to rock in quarries, not ore; s.2(g) covers processes in scheduled employment only.

holdings.text: the impugned notification issued by the State Government under s. 5 2  is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: the impugned notification issued by the State Government under s. 5 2  is ultra vires. The High Court has referred to the fact that in describing some items in Part I the word any has been used whereas the said word has not been used in item 8.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(2) empowers fixation only for scheduled employments; operations not in Schedule; distinct from s.27 power to add employments.

holdings.text: the impugned notification does not purport to add any item in Schedule I

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, clear that the impugned notification does not purport to add any item in Schedule I and that was also not the case of the appellant. Thus the assumption made by the High Court on both the points is, with respect, erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct reading of notification text; High Court misdirected itself.

holdings.text: the High Court was in error in assuming that the vires of the impugned notification had been conceded by the appellant before it

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was in error in assuming that the vires of the impugned notification had been conceded by the appellant before it. This is another serious infirmity in the judgment of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition, certificate of fitness, statement of case show vires challenged as ultra vires s.5(2).

holdings.text: it is open to the appellant to claim a writ against the respondents even without challenging the vires of the Presidential notification
holdings.reasoning_summary: No agency in commission of wrong; wrongdoer liable directly; precedent in Thangal Kunju; parity with Art.226 writ jurisdiction.

holdings.text: the impugned notification issued by respondent 2 is invalid and cannot be enforced
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: ultra vires s.5(2) as not scheduled employment.

holdings.text: what can be done by the appropriate government in exercise of its power under s. 27 cannot be done by it in exercise of its power under s. 5 2

anchor.surface_text: The nature and extent of the said two powers are thus quite separate and distinct and there can be no doubt that what can be done by the appropriate government in exercise of its power under s. 27 cannot be done by it in exercise of its power under s. 5 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act distinguishes: s.5(2) for existing scheduled, s.27 to add new.

holdings.text: the appropriate government may, and can, act under s. 27 of the Act if it is desired that the employment in mines or in connection with any operations incidental to mining should be governed by the provisions of the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper procedure to extend Act to mines via s.27.

holdings.text: an occasion for showing preference for one construction rather than the other can legitimately arise only when two constructions are reasonably possible, not otherwise

anchor.surface_text: but it is obvious that an occasion for showing preference for one construction rather than the other can legitimately arise only when two constructions are reasonably possible, not otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits to beneficent construction in welfare statutes.

precedents.cited_proposition: there can be no agency in the matter of a commission of a wrong; the wrong-doer is liable directly responsible for his wrongful action even if acting as agent
precedents.cited_holding: there can be no agency in the matter of a commission of a wrong. The wrong-doer would certainly be liable to be dealt with as a party directly responsible for his wrongful action, and it was added that on the analogy of a civil wrong the tortfeasor could certainly not protect himself against the liability on the ground of having committed the tort under the directions of his principal

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, our conclusion is that the stone-breaking or stone-crushing operations which are carried on in mines are not included in item 8 in the Schedule and if that be the true position the impugned notification issued by the State Government under s. 5 2  is ultra vires.
In the result we hold that the impugned numberification issued by respondent 2 is invalid and cannot be enforced.
